Award.AwardTitle: NRI: RUI: Autonomous Vehicles: Ethics, Design, and Risk

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research project will examine ethical issues that arise in connection with autonomous vehicles (such as self-driving cars), from programming choices to guarding against abuse. Collaborators include engineers, philosophers, and legal experts. Autonomous vehicles are starting to emerge, and they are predicted to solve a lot of problems, especially traffic accidents and fatalities. But they will not be foolproof, meaning that (just like any other technology) they will be subject to error, misuse, and failure, and some designs may be better or more responsible than others. Even if autonomous vehicles can save thousands of lives each year, industry and researchers are not thereby released from the obligation to consider ethical, legal, and policy implications of the bringing about of unnecessary and wrongful deaths. The loss of lives in this way could have a devastating, high profile effect on the nascent industry. The results of this project will benefit both industry and the academia. Deliverables will include a public report, a book, university-level courses, conference talks, and academic as well as media publications. Beyond the autonomous driving industry, this project provides research and materials in robot ethics and technology ethics more broadly, as pressure mounts to integrate ethics into engineering and science programs.

The PI and his team will examine the different ways that an autonomous vehicle could be involved in an accident, as well as crash-avoidance and crash-optimization options to mitigate the harm that occurs in unavoidable crashes. They will also investigate the technical and policy feasibility of various ethical frameworks to guide actions by autonomous vehicles by drawing from classical dilemmas in ethics, ongoing work in technology ethics, and real engineering in academic and industry labs on the front lines. They will also attend to broader issues, such as how autonomous cars should handle medical emergencies, criminal conduct, and other common situations. The project is aligned with the NSF's mission, as well as the call of its NRI program for research to gain a better understanding of the long-term social, behavioral and economic implications of co-robots. Because autonomous vehicles are poised to be the first robots to be integrated with society on a large scale, they will set the tone for the entire social or co-robotics industry. It is crucially important to engage ethics ahead of these developments to consider the issues and scenarios in advance of potentially high-profile accidents.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Few emerging technologies have captured the public imagination recently like autonomous vehicles, taking over the process of driving from humans. These cars promise benefits for safety, environmental impact, convenience, and more. However, the hype surrounding this and many other emerging technologies—whether positive or negative—can distort the public discourse at a crucial decision point. Secondly, even when the debates take place in academia, they are often siloed in their respective disciplines, so that engineers, lawyers, ethicists, etc., rarely sit down with one another to see how their expertise might be mutually beneficial.

However, when it comes to the ethical, legal, and social implications (ELSI) of emerging technologies, these discussions necessarily require the input of multiple disciplines, and they demand informed, careful public debate. Our project has been driven by these two motivations: to bring together interdisciplinary teams of scholars producing the highest quality academic and legal work on autonomous vehicles, and then to digest and disseminate that information to the public at multiple levels: within the university and beyond. Here is a brief summary of how we have carried out the goals of this project.

Over the course of two years, we produced many products for the public. These include a report, titled “Autonomous Vehicles Ethics & Law: Toward and Overlapping Consensus,” published by the New America Foundation. This report collected two days of expert input from our workshop at Stanford concerning questions such as: “Is it reasonable to prioritize the safety of an AV’s occupants versus people outside the car?”, “Should we ever expect a vehicle that can operate autonomously in all conditions?”, and “What should consumers be told about how their vehicle might operate in the event of a crash?”, among many others. The report distills key insights from this meeting to a form accessible by the industry and the public.

Other written research outputs include an edited collection of expert essays in Robot Ethics 2.0: From Autonomous Vehicles to Artificial Intelligence, to be published this year by Oxford University Press. This book will serve as a companion to a new course we have developed and implemented, titled “Robot Ethics.” By teaching a course directly engaged with the ethical questions in robot design, our goal is to ensure that the next generation of roboticists considers the ethics of their design choices from the first day they embark on their career, and as an empowering toolkit, rather than a list of Ten Commandments-style prohibitions on their work. In our meetings with industry—for this grant, we have presented at the National Academies’ Transportation Research Board, RSA Security, Apple, and Daimler, among others—we always stress our role as facilitators who help illuminate the overlooked ethical corners of these debates, rather than moralizers who drop in to slap the hands of engineers.

Alongside these, we have given dozens of academic and public lectures and scripted an animated TED-Ed video which has garnered over half a million views. Our public writings appear in venues such as Forbes and the Washington Post and consider questions such as, “Is the ‘trolley problem’ really the right way to think about autonomous car crash dilemmas?”, “Could driverless cars harm people that humans would not?”, “What are the hidden ethical dilemmas in everyday scenarios, such as navigation and lane-positioning decisions?”, and others.

Raising awareness of the subject, these popular media pieces have been read widely and are usually the first articles to raise their specific issues. A quick survey shows that they have been shared thousands of times across social media platforms. We have also been interviewed for 40+ pieces in The Atlantic, NPR, Fast Company, and other major publications.

In the course of our investigations, we often discover surprising connections to other domains. In this case, our investigations into autonomous cars have revealed insights into the ethics of autonomous weapons (i.e. “killer robots”) and led us to partner with the UN to organize two workshops on the subject as well. This is proof positive that there is such a thing as “basic research” into the ethics of emerging technologies, since they raise interlocking questions, in this case, about the ethical responsibility for autonomous designs and the legal implications of machines that think on their own.

Autonomous vehicles aren’t just a revolution in transportation, but they will set the tone for all of social or co-robotics; and they inform similar discussions with other autonomous and connected systems (e.g., Internet of Things). These are all important technologies, and the world is closely watching how autonomous vehicles develop and are deployed, especially as it relates to risk and safety. Ultimately, we continue to unite high-quality interdisciplinary research on emerging technologies with an overarching concern for public education and engagement, to help ensure a more complete understanding of how these technologies may affect the fabric of our lives.
